This is a '''Timeline Of Scientology''', particularly its foundation and development by author [[L. Ron Hubbard]]. {{TOC right}}
==1938== * [[L. Ron Hubbard]] authors a manuscript called "[[Excalibur (L. Ron Hubbard)|Excalibur]]" which contains ideas that were later incorporated into Scientology.<ref name="expreli">{{cite book |author=Chryssides, George D. |title=Exploring new religions |publisher=Cassell |location=London |year=1999 |pages=281 |isbn=0-8264-5959-5}}</ref>
==1949== * First published work on Dianetics appeared in the Winter/Spring issue of the ''Explorers Club Journal'' entitled "Terra Incognita: The Mind". At this time, he offered his findings on the mind to both the [[American Medical Association]] and the [[American Psychiatric Association]]. Both organizations rejected them.<ref name="parents">{{cite journal|last=Eisenberg | first=Ellen|title=The Dangerous New Cult of Scientology|publisher=[[Parents (magazine)|Parents Magazine]]|date=June 1969}}</ref>
==1950s== ===1950=== * On May 9, 1950 L. Ron Hubbard's ''[[Dianetics: The Modern Science of Mental Health|Dianetics — The Modern Science of Mental Health]]'' was published.<ref>{{cite news | title = Of Two Minds | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,812852,00.html | work = [[Time (magazine)|TIME Magazine]] | date = 1950-07-24 | accessdate = 2008-10-02 }}</ref> * In August 1950, amidst the success of ''Dianetics'', Hubbard held a demonstration in Los Angeles' [[Shrine Auditorium]] where he presented a young woman called Sonya Bianca (a pseudonym) to a large audience including many reporters and photographers as "the world's first [[Clear (Scientology)|Clear]]." However, despite Hubbard's claim that she had "full and perfect recall of every moment of her life", Bianca proved unable to answer questions from the audience testing her memory and analytical abilities, including the question of the color of Hubbard's tie. Hubbard explained Bianca's failure to display her promised powers of recall to the audience by saying that he had used the word "now" in calling her to the stage, and thus inadvertently froze her in "present time", which blocked her abilities.<ref>{{cite book|first=Russell|last=Miller|title=Bare-Faced Messiah: The True Story of L. Ron Hubbard|year=1987|isbn=0-8050-0654-0}}</ref><ref name="atack"/> Later, in the late 1950s, Hubbard would claim that several people had reached the state of Clear by the time he presented Bianca as the world's first; these others, Hubbard said, he had successfully cleared in the late 1940s while working ''incognito'' in Hollywood posing as a [[swami]].<ref>{{cite speech| first=L. Ron| last=Hubbard| title=The Story of Dianetics and Scientology, Lecture 18| date=October 1958| quote="by 1947, I had achieved clearing."}}</ref> In 1966, Hubbard declared South African Scientologist John McMaster to be the first true Clear.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Alan|last=Levy|title=Scientology|journal=Life|date=1968-11-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first=Wendy|last=Michener|title=Is This the Happiest Man in the World?|journal=Maclean's|date=1966-08-22}}</ref> McMaster left the [[Sea Org]] in November 1969, expressing continuing belief in the Scientology [[Scientology beliefs and practices|Tech]], but disapproval of the way Scientology was managed.<ref name="atack">{{cite book|first=Jon|last=Atack|title=A Piece of Blue Sky: Scientology, Dianetics and L. Ron Hubbard Exposed|year=1990|isbn=0-8184-0499-X}}</ref> * “Dianetics: Evolution of a Science” was published in Astounding Science Fiction, whose editor was John W. Campbell, an early Dianetics enthusiast.<ref name=lewis2017/> * Hubbard Dianetics Research Foundation established in Elizabeth, New Jersey.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1951=== * June: [[Science of Survival]] was published. * A Doctor’s Report on Dianetics published by medical doctor and Dianetics enthusiast Joseph A. Winter.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1952=== *Early Dianetics supporter Joseph Winter M.D. breaks with Hubbard, convinced "that it is dangerous for laymen to try to audit each other".<ref>{{cite news | title = Departure in Dianetics | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,821638,00.html | work = [[Time (magazine)|TIME Magazine]] | date = 1951-09-03 | accessdate = 2008-10-14 }}</ref> *May 1952 – Hubbard’s Dianetics Center moves to Phoenix. Phoenix is considered the “birthplace of Scientology.”<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1952=== * February: After learning that the ''Hubbard Dianetic Foundation'' of [[Wichita, Kansas]] would be liable for the debts of the defunct ''Hubbard Dianetic Research Foundation'' of [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]], the board of directors, led by Don Purcell, voted to file for [[voluntary bankruptcy]] over Hubbard's objections. Hubbard forms a rival ''Hubbard College'', also in Wichita, and disputes control of the copyrights of the Dianetics materials.<ref name="Bare-faced">Miller, Russell ''Bare-faced messiah: The true story of L. Ron Hubbard'', publisher M. Joseph (1987) {{ISBN|0-7181-2764-1}}</ref><!--pg.199--> * May: Hubbard publicly announces the formal establishment of the philosophy of Scientology and the formation of the ''Hubbard Association of Scientologists International'', demonstrates the [[E-meter]], and moves to [[Phoenix, Arizona]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Remember Venus? | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,889564,00.html | work = [[Time (magazine)|TIME Magazine]] | date = 1952-12-22 | accessdate = 2008-10-02 }}</ref> * July: [[Scientology: A History of Man]] published.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}
===1953=== * Church of Scientology, Church of American Science and Church of Spiritual Engineering incorporated in [[Elizabeth, New Jersey]] by L. Ron Hubbard. Co-signatories were Henrietta Hubbard, [[Ronald DeWolf|L. Ron Hubbard Jr.]], John Galusha, Verna Greenough and Barbara Bryan. Named as trustees of the Church of Scientology were L. Ron Hubbard, [[Mary Sue Hubbard]] (not present), and John Galusha.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiseoldgoat.com/papers-scientology/popup-windows/scn_incorp2_church_scientology.html|title=Certificate of Incorporation: The Church of Scientology (New Jersey)|website=wiseoldgoat.com}}</ref>
===1954=== * The [[Church of Scientology]] is incorporated in California and Arizona.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} * The [[Internal Revenue Service]] grants a tax exemption to the Church of Scientology of California (CSC).{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}
===1955=== * April: The [[Hubbard Association of Scientologists International]] holds the First Australian Scientology Congress in [[Prahran, Victoria]], Australia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article65383944 |title=Advertising. |newspaper=[[Healesville Guardian]] |location=Lilydale, Vic. |date=18 March 1955 |accessdate=13 August 2013 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * July: The Founding Church of Scientology, now known as the [[Original Founding Church of Scientology]] was organized in Washington, D.C.<ref name="WCP">{{cite web| last=Banville | first=Jule | title=The L. Ron Hubbard House: Get There Before Travolta | work=[[Washington City Paper]]| date=2007-09-11 | url=http://www.washingtoncitypaper.com/blogs/citydesk/2007/09/11/the-l-ron-hubbard-house-get-there-before-travolta/ | accessdate=2009-04-03}}</ref>
===1956=== * The church is recognized as a tax-exempt religious organization in the United States.<ref name=DHDavis />
===1959=== * Hubbard moved to England and bought Saint Hill Manor in [[Sussex]], from which he would direct international operations and expansion until 1967.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}
==1960s== ===1963=== * January 4: The [[US Food and Drug Administration]] raided the [[Original Founding Church of Scientology]] and seized approximately 100 of the Church's [[E-meter]]s as illegal medical devices. The devices are now required to carry a disclaimer saying that they are a purely religious artifact. They are used in a Scientology counseling technique known as "auditing".<ref>{{cite court |litigants=United States of America v. Founding Church of Scientology |vol=333 F |reporter= |opinion=1–63 |pinpoint= |court=[[United States District Court for the District of Columbia|D.C.]] |year=1971 |url=http://www.lermanet.com/case2.htm |quote= }}</ref>
===1965=== * The Church of Scientology was banned in several Australian states, starting with [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]].<ref name="Melton14">{{cite book |last=Melton |first=J. Gordon |authorlink=J. Gordon Melton |title=The Church of Scientology |publisher=Signature Press |year=2000 |location=Salt Lake City |isbn=978-1-56085-139-4 |postscript=|p=14}}</ref> The ban was based on the [[Anderson Report]], which found that the auditing process involved "command" hypnosis, in which the hypnotist assumes "positive authoritative control" over the patient."<ref>''Report of the Board of Enquiry into Scientology'' by Kevin Victor Anderson, Q.C. Published 1965 by the State of Victoria, Australia, p. 155</ref> * Classification, Gradation and Awareness Chart released in East Grinstead, United Kingdom <ref name=lewis2017>{{cite book |title=Handbook of Scientology |volume=Brill Handbooks on Contemporary Religion |editor1-last=Lewis |editor1-first=James R. |editor1-link=James R. Lewis (scholar)|editor2-last=Hellesoy |editor2-first=Kjersti |publisher=Brill |year=2017 |isbn=9789004330542 }}</ref>
===1966=== * [[Narconon]] founded. * August 1966 - OT I released. * September 1966 - OT II released.<ref name=lewis2017/> * John McMaster announced as first true clear.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1967=== * The IRS strips the Church of Scientology in California, Scientology's headquarters, of its tax-exempt status, asserting that its activities are commercial and operated for the benefit of Mr. Hubbard, rather than charitable or religious reasons.<ref name=DHDavis /> * [[Xenu|OT III]] is made available to Scientologists. This level of [[Operating Thetan]] contains the story of [[Xenu]], which becomes a source of enormous controversy for Scientology from the 1990s onward.<ref name=lewis2017/> * The Sea Organization (or Sea Org) officially established.<ref>{{cite book |author1=Hankins, Barry |author2=Davis, Derek Russell |title=New Religious Movements and Religious Liberty in America |publisher=Baylor University Press |location=Waco, Tex |year=2003 |pages=46 |isbn=0-918954-92-4}}</ref> * December 27: The first Advanced Organization, offering the advanced levels of Scientology to the public, was established aboard the Royal Scotman, the flagship of the Sea Organization. (This ship was later renamed the Apollo.){{Citation needed|date=February 2008}}
===1968=== * Introduction to Scientology Ethics is published.{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}} * August 1968 – Freedom Magazine Founded by Church of Scientology.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1969=== * The U.S. court of appeals recognizes Scientology as a religion, marking the high point of the case of Scientology vs. the FDA.<ref name="cults83">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aqmbnfXCzn0C&pg=PA189&dq=dianetics&lr=&as_brr=3&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA83,M1|title=Cults|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> * Standard Dianetics released.<ref name=lewis2017/> * Citizens Commission on Human Rights (CCHR) founded in the United States.<ref name=lewis2017/>
==1970s== ===1970=== * February 22: Church of Scientology Celebrity Centre in Los Angeles founded.<ref name=lewis2017/> * Criminon founded.<ref name=lewis2017/> * November: Hubbard begins delivery of Flag Executive Briefing<ref name=lewis2017/> * Personal Spiritual Freedoms Foundation - later called Dianology and then Eductivism, established by Jack Horner<ref name=lewis2017/> * Scientology: The Now Religion published by journalist George Malko<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1971=== * The FDA is ordered to return the materials and E-meters seized during the 1963 raid.<ref name="cults83"/>
===1974=== * January 23, 1974 - Introspection Rundown released.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1975=== * Scientologists buy former [[Fort Harrison Hotel]] and old Bank of Clearwater.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} *Scientology is recognized as a non-profit organization in South Africa, despite the 1972 report of a formal government Commission of Inquiry that recommended otherwise.<ref>[http://www.emanationinc.com/Chidestr/pagei.htm Scientology: A Religion in South Africa by David Chidester, University of Cape Town, South Africa] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513132738/http://www.emanationinc.com/Chidestr/pagei.htm |date=May 13, 2008 }}</ref>
===1977=== * Various locations of the Church of Scientology are raided by the [[FBI]].<ref name=Burglaries_and_Lies>{{cite news | first = Robert W. | last = Welkos |author2=Sappell, Joel | title = Burglaries and Lies Paved a Path to Prison | url = http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-scientologysidec062490,0,7034344.story | work = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date = 1990-06-24 | accessdate = 2008-10-02 }}</ref>
===1978=== * New Era Dianetics released.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1979=== * As a result of [[FBI]] raids, eleven senior people in the church's [[Guardian's Office]] were convicted of obstructing justice, burglary of government offices, and theft of documents and government property. (See [[Operation Snow White]])<ref name=Burglaries_and_Lies/> * March: Hubbard Mark IV E-meter released.<ref name=lewis2017/> * December: An estimated 3,000 gather at Clearwater City Hall to protest the church coming to Clearwater. Across the street, Scientologists stage a counter rally, dressed as clowns and wearing animal costumes.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} * December: Purification Rundown released.<ref name=lewis2017/>
==1980s== [[Image:Scientology-nyc.jpg|thumb|Center in New York City]]
===1980=== * Acquisition of the former [[The White Rats|White Rats]] Club building at 227 West 46th in the Broadway [[Theater District]] in New York City. The building was built in 1912 and the church acquired it from the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE2DE1E3CF932A35750C0A961948260 | work=The New York Times | title=Q And A | first=Shawn G. | last=Kennedy | date=1987-03-01 | accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref> * January - New OT IV released.<ref name=lewis2017/> * August – Golden Era Productions established.<ref name=lewis2017/> * September – New OT V (Hubbard Solo New Era Dianetics for OTs) and OT VII released.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1981=== * February - The Way to Happiness: A Common Sense Guide to Better Living published.<ref name=lewis2017/> * November 19 – Church of Scientology International (CSI) founded.<ref name=lewis2017/> * December – Scientology Missions International founded.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1982=== * Clearwater's government holds [[Clearwater Hearings|hearings]] to explore allegations that the church is a cult.<ref name="Scientology: The 1982 Clearwater Hearings (YouTube Playlist)">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLB8A8C6C0BFB607D1|title=Scientology: The 1982 Clearwater Hearings|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Lermanet.Com: 1982 Clearwater Commission Hearings">{{cite web|url=http://www.lermanet.com/82cwcommission|title=1982 Clearwater commission Hearings|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref><ref name="St. Petersburg Times: Special Report on Scientology">[http://www.antisectes.net/sp-times-scientology-special-report-pulitzer-price.pdf#page=3 St. Petersburg Times: Special Report on Scientology] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160124225356/http://www.antisectes.net/sp-times-scientology-special-report-pulitzer-price.pdf |date=January 24, 2016 }}></ref> * May – Church of Spiritual Technology Incorporated.<ref name=lewis2017/> * Battlefield Earth published.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1983=== * The [[High Court of Australia]] overturns the Scientology ban, declaring that "The applicant has easily discharged the onus of showing that it is religious. The conclusion that it is a religious institution entitled to the tax exemption is irresistible."<ref name=HCOA>High Court of Australia [http://www.uniset.ca/other/cs6/154CLR120.html ''CHURCH OF THE NEW FAITH v. COMMISSIONER OF PAY-ROLL TAX (VICT.) 1983 154 CLR 120'']</ref> * The Church of Scientology of Toronto is raided. (See [[R. v. Church of Scientology of Toronto]])<ref>{{cite news | first = W. Richard | last = Reynolds | title = Scientology church on trial in Canada | url = https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sptimes/access/50624765.html?dids=50624765:50624765&FMT=FT | work = [[St. Petersburg Times]] | date = 1991-04-23 | accessdate = 2008-10-03 }}</ref> * December - Office of Special Affairs International formed.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1985=== * The Church of Scientology acquires yacht "[[Bohème]]" and renames it to "[[Freewinds]]".{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} * October - First of ten volumes of Mission Earth published.<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1986=== * January 24: Hubbard dies at his ranch near [[San Luis Obispo, California]].<ref>{{cite web | title = L. Ron Hubbard, Church of Scientology founder, dies | url = http://www.seattlepi.com/archives/1986/8601020951.asp | work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date = 1986-01-28 | accessdate = 2008-10-03 }}</ref> * [[David Miscavige]], Chairman of the Board of the [[Author Services Inc.]], becomes head.{{Citation needed|date=October 2008}}
==1990s== ===1991=== * After the completion of a 4-year long program to reissue the books and courses of Dianetics and Scientology, a general amnesty is declared for members.{{Citation needed|date=February 2008}} * September - Streamlined Bridge to Total Freedom released (grade chart).<ref name=lewis2017/>
===1992=== * June: The Church of Scientology is found guilty on two counts of breach of the public trust in [[Ontario]], Canada in [[R. v. Church of Scientology of Toronto]] and fined $250,000. Seven members are also convicted.<ref>{{cite news | title = Church of Scientology fined $250,000 for espionage | first = Thomas | last = Claridge | work = [[The Globe and Mail]] | date = 1992-09-12}}</ref>
===1993=== * December: The [[Internal Revenue Service]] of the United States grants full religious recognition and tax exemption to all Scientology Churches, [[Scientology Missions International|missions]] and social betterment groups in that country.<ref name=DHDavis /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.snafu.de/tilman/krasel/da/da_germany1.html|title=IRS Letter to the German Federal minister for family and youth|website=home.snafu.de}}</ref>
===1994=== * December 24: a number of Scientology's confidential [[Operating Thetan]] documents are published on the newsgroup ''[[alt.religion.scientology]]'' through an [[anonymous remailer]]. This marks the beginning of Scientology's online activities, often referred to as [[Scientology versus the Internet]].<ref>{{cite web | first = David | last = Post | title = New World War | url = http://www.reason.com/news/show/29894.html | work = [[Reason Magazine]] | date = 1996-04-01 | accessdate = 2008-10-14 }}</ref>
===1995=== * July 20: The Supreme Court of Canada upholds the largest libel award in Canadian history against the Church of Scientology. (See [[Hill v. Church of Scientology of Toronto]])<ref>{{lexum-scc2|1995|2|1130|59}}</ref> * December 5: [[Lisa McPherson]], a 36-year-old [[Scientologist]] dies after 17 days under the care of [[Church of Scientology Flag Service Organization]]. Police begin an investigation the following day.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Frantz|first1=Douglas|title=DISTRUST IN CLEARWATER -- A special report.; Death of a Scientologist Heightens Suspicions in a Florida Town|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/01/us/distrust-clearwater-special-report-death-scientologist-heightens-suspicions.html|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=The New York Times|date=1 December 1997}}</ref>
===1996=== * The Church releases the Golden Age of Tech program with the express goal of improving and speeding up the training of its practitioners. * On 21 November 1996, Don Jason, a Scientology Chief Officer with prior authority over hundreds of staff in [[Clearwater, Florida]], escaped from the [[Scientology]] church by jumping off their 440-foot-long ship named [[Freewinds]] that was docked at the time in the [[Bahamas]]. As he had escaped the church (Scientology vernacular: “blown”) earlier that year in August, he was barred from leaving Freewinds, his [[passport]] confiscated. Running from the ship, he jumped into a waiting [[taxicab]], closing the door on a Scientology guard's hand, and screamed to the driver: "I'm being held against my will! Take me to a g-- d---[[airport]]!''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/scientology/man-overboard-to-leave-scientology-don-jason-had-to-jump-off-a-ship/1048124|title=Man overboard: To leave Scientology, Don Jason had to jump off a ship|date=November 3, 2009|website=tampabay.com}}</ref>
===1997=== * February: McPherson's family files a [[Wrongful death claim|wrongful-death]] lawsuit against the church.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Waldrip|first1=Cheryl|title=Suit accuses Scientologists of negligence in death|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=TT&p_theme=tt&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_field_label-0=Author&p_field_label-1=title&p_bool_label-1=AND&s_dispstring=scientology%20death%20AND%20date(1/1/1997%20to%202/28/1997)&p_field_date-0=YMD_date&p_params_date-0=date:B,E&p_text_date-0=1/1/1997%20to%202/28/1997)&p_field_advanced-0=&p_text_advanced-0=(scientology%20death)&xcal_numdocs=20&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&xcal_useweights=no|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=Tampa Tribune|date=20 February 1997}}{{paywall|date=February 2015}}</ref> * The Church of Scientology, operating as the Greek Center of Applied Philosophy, is ordered closed in Greece. Decision upheld in 1998.<ref>{{cite news|first=Lucy |last=Morgan |title=Abroad: Critics public and private keep pressure on Scientology |url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/32999/Worldandnation/Abroad__Critics_publi.html |publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]] |date=1999-03-29 |accessdate=September 15, 2006 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yLc3T9Xn?url=http://www.sptimes.com/News/32999/Worldandnation/Abroad__Critics_publi.html |archivedate=May 1, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
===1998=== * November: After reviewing the McPherson case for 11 months, State Attorney Bernie McCabe charges the Church of Scientology with two felonies: practicing medicine without a license and abuse of a disabled adult. Also, the church begins construction of the [[Flag Building]], launching a $160-million construction project in downtown Clearwater, Florida.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/humaninterest/church-of-scientology-sets-opening-of-long-delayed-flag-building-in/2136935|title=Church of Scientology sets opening of long-delayed Flag Building in Clearwater|date=August 17, 2013|website=tampabay.com}}</ref>
===1999=== * The [[Charity Commission for England and Wales]] denies the Church of Scientology's application for charitable status, ruling that it is not a religion and that there is no established "public benefit arising out of the practice of Scientology".<ref name=Wallop /><ref name=USSUK>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2007/90206.htm|title=United Kingdom|website=state.gov}}</ref><ref name=cosfulldoc>{{cite web | url = http://www.charity-commission.gov.uk/Library/start/cosdecsum.pdf|format=PDF|title = Decision of the Charity Commissioners for England and Wales |date = 1999-11-17|publisher = [[Charity Commission for England and Wales|Charity Commission]] | accessdate = 2006-07-06 }} (PDF)</ref> The Church does not appeal the decision.<ref name=USSUK /> * November: The government of Sweden declares that the Church of Scientology is a charitable, non-profit organization with a religious purpose.<ref name=DHDavis /> A year later, the Church's ministers are granted the right to perform marriages, completing official recognition as a church in Sweden.<ref name=DHDavis /> * [[Bob Minton]], a banker critical of Scientology, starts a protest organization called the [[Lisa McPherson Trust]]. The organization picketed Scientology buildings on the anniversary of McPherson's death. The group was disbanded in November 2001.<ref>{{cite news|last1=O'Neil|first1=Deborah|title=How Scientology turned its biggest critic|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2002/07/07/TampaBay/How_Scientology_turne.shtml|accessdate=17 February 2015|work=St. Petersburg Times|date=7 July 2002}}</ref>
==2000s== ===2000=== * March: The Italian Supreme Court upholds Scientology's religious status in Italy while reaffirming that Narconon is a non-tax-exempt for-profit business.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cesnur.org/testi/scie_march2000.htm|title=Italy: Scientology Religious but Narconon Not Tax-Exempt|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> * Scientology ministers are granted the right to perform marriages in South Africa.<ref name="MARRIAGE">{{cite web |url = http://www.cesnur.org/testi/scient_SouthA.htm |title = Scientology Marriage Officers Approved in South Africa |date = 2000-04-11 |accessdate = 2007-07-21 |publisher = [[CESNUR]]}}</ref> * In the United Kingdom, the Church of Scientology is exempted from [[value added tax]] on the basis that it is a not-for-profit body.<ref name=Wallop>Harry Wallop: [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/money/main.jhtml?xml=/money/2006/08/11/cntax11.xml Scientology tax victory could cost Revenue millions], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', Aug. 11, 2006</ref> * June: McCabe drops the criminal case against the church, noting that the medical examiner's change of opinion about the cause of McPherson's death undercuts the prosecution's effort to prove the criminal case beyond a reasonable doubt.<ref>{{cite web | first = Thomas C. | last = Tobin | title = State drops charges against Scientology | url = http://www.sptimes.com/News/061300/TampaBay/State_drops_charges_a.shtml | work = [[St. Petersburg Times]] | date = 2000-06-13 | accessdate = 2008-10-14 }}</ref>
===2002=== *The government of New Zealand issues an official decree fully recognizing the Church of Scientology of New Zealand as an exempt religious and charitable organization.<ref name=DHDavis> {{cite conference |first=Derek H. |last=Davis |title=The Church of Scientology: In Pursuit of Legal Recognition |booktitle=Zeitdiagnosen: Religion and Conformity |pages= |publisher=Lit Verlag |year=2004 |location=Münster, Germany |url=http://www.umhb.edu/files/academics/crl/publications/articles/the_church_of_scientologypursuit_of_legal_recognition.pdf |format=PDF |doi= |id= |accessdate=2008-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5o4YGXMBa?url=http://www.umhb.edu/files/academics/crl/publications/articles/the_church_of_scientologypursuit_of_legal_recognition.pdf |archivedate=March 8, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name=NZH>{{cite web |url = http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/1/story.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=3048935 |title = Scientology gets tax-exempt status |accessdate = 2007-08-01 |date = 2002-12-27 |work = [[New Zealand Herald]] |quote = the IRD said the church was a charitable organisation dedicated to the advancement of religion}}</ref>
* The Austrian tax office concludes that the work of the Church of Scientology in [[Vienna]] is for the public benefit rather than anyone's personal profit, and grants that church tax-exempt status as a charitable religious organization.<ref name=DHDavis /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2003/27825.htm|title=Austria|website=state.gov}}</ref> * July: A Paris judge rules that a 13-year-old case against the Church of Scientology alleging fraud and illegal practice of medicine cannot go to trial, due to lack of progress in the investigation.<ref name=SLTFrance> {{Cite news | last =Staff | title =FRANCE Statute of limitations nixes case against Church of Scientology | newspaper =[[The Salt Lake Tribune]] | pages = | date =July 31, 2002 | url =http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SLTB&p_theme=sltb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=100E45F960F3F599&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM | ref =harv | postscript =<!--None--> }}.</ref> The judge rules that the [[statute of limitations]] has expired.<ref name=SLTFrance />
===2003=== * March: The National Ministry of the Interior for [[Taiwan]] recognizes the Church of Scientology of Taiwan as a charitable religious institution, officially adding it to the rolls of the country's recognized religions.<ref name=DHDavis />
===2004=== * May: The church and the estate of Lisa McPherson reach a private settlement.<ref>{{cite news|last=Farley|first=Robert|title=Scientologists settle death suit|publisher=[[St. Petersburg Times]]|date=May 29, 2004|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/05/29/Tampabay/Scientologists_settle.shtml|accessdate=April 7, 2009}}</ref>
===2005=== * The U.S. Department of State's 2005 Report on International Religious Freedom announces that the Church of Scientology has been registered as a religious group by the [[Kyrgyzstan]] State Commission on Religious Affairs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2005/51562.htm|title=Kyrgyzstan|work=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> * David Miscavige announces the Golden Age of Knowledge, a Church program intended to make all Scientology materials available. It starts with the release of 18 congresses.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scientologynews.org/david-miscavige/a-renaissance-for-scientology.html|title=A Renaissance for Scientology|website=Scientology}}</ref>
===2006=== * Scientology applies for status as a religious confessional community in Austria, but later withdraws its application.<ref name=USStateAustria>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/irf/2006/71367.htm|title=Austria|work=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref>
===2007===
* In the next major step of the Golden Age of Knowledge program, 18 revised books and 11 lecture series are released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/news/scientology/pervasive-pitch-scientology-book-and-lecture-series-the-basics-unleashes-a/1201177|title=Pervasive pitch: Scientology book and lecture series, 'The Basics,' unleashes a sales frenzy|date=November 13, 2011|website=tampabay.com}}</ref> * April: the [[European Court of Human Rights]] [[Church of Scientology Moscow versus Russia|rules against Russia]] for repeatedly refusing to consider the Moscow Church of Scientology's application for the status of a legally valid religious association. The court finds that the reasons given to deny re-registration of the church by the justice department and endorsed by the Moscow courts have no legal basis.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cmiskp.echr.coe.int/tkp197/view.asp?action=html&documentId=815108&portal=hbkm&source=externalbydocnumber&table=F69A27FD8FB86142BF01C1166DEA398649|title=HUDOC Search Page|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?from=rss_World&set_id=1&click_id=3&art_id=nw20070405161359229C589107|title=Scientologists 1, Russia 0|author=Independent Newspapers Online|work=Independent Online|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> * A [[Belgium|Belgian]] state prosecutor recommends that a case should be brought against 12 physical persons associated with Scientology and two legal entities – the Belgian Church of Scientology and Scientology's Office of Human Rights – on counts of extortion, fraud, organized crime, obstruction of medical practice, illegal medical practice, invasion of privacy, conspiracy and commercial infractions like abusive contractual clauses.<ref name=foxbel /><ref name=Planchar>{{cite web | first = Roland | last = Planchar | title = La Scientologie plus près de son procès | url = http://www.lalibre.be/article.phtml?id=10&subid=90&art_id=368037 | publisher = La Libre Belgique | date = 2007-09-04 | accessdate = 2007-09-04|language=fr}}</ref> The proposal is referred to an administrative court who is to decide at a later date whether charges will be brought.<ref name=foxbel>{{cite news| url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,295693,00.html | work=Fox News | title=Church of Scientology Faces Criminal Charges in Belgium | date=2007-09-04}}</ref><ref name=Planchar /> * October 31: Scientology is formally recognized as a religion in Spain<ref name="afpspain">{{cite web |url=http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5h-V0Ui506lPl-r8ImubpdUjFbuYA |title=Spanish court rules Scientology can be listed as a religion |publisher=AFP |date=November 1, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071226104617/http://afp.google.com/article/ALeqM5h-V0Ui506lPl-r8ImubpdUjFbuYA |archivedate=December 26, 2007 |df= }}</ref><ref name="Elpais"> {{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/sociedad/Audiencia/Nacional/reconoce/Cienciologia/iglesia/elpepusoc/20071101elpepisoc_8/Tes |title=La Audiencia Nacional reconoce a la Cienciología como iglesia |work=El País |date=November 1, 2007}} {{Link language|es}}<!--Spanish--></ref>
* November: Scientology is officially recognized as a religion in Portugal.<ref name=USSPortugal>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100579.htm|title=Country Report on Human Rights Practices in Portugal|work=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> * December 3: South Africa grants the Church tax exemption and issues a certificate recognizing it as a "Public Benefit Organisation".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.int.iol.co.za/index.php?set_id=1&click_id=594&art_id=nw20071204183608671C621249|title=SA Church of Scientology gets tax exemption|website=iol.co.za}}</ref> * December 7: German federal and state interior ministers formally express the view that the Scientology organization continues to pursue anti-constitutional goals and ask Germany's domestic intelligence agencies to collect and evaluate the necessary information that would be required for a possible judicial inquiry aimed at banning the organization.<ref name="TS8-12-08"/><ref>[http://www.im.nrw.de/inn/doks/imk1207.pdf Sammlung der zur Veröffentlichung freigegebenen Beschlüsse der 185. Sitzung der Ständigen Konferenz der Innenminister und -senatoren der Länder am 7. Dezember 2007 in Berlin] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090319091548/http://www.im.nrw.de/inn/doks/imk1207.pdf |date=March 19, 2009 }} {{Link language|de}}<!--German--></ref> The move is criticized by politicians from all parts of the political spectrum, with legal experts expressing concern that an attempt to ban the organization would most likely fail in the courts.<ref name="TS8-12-08">[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/zeitung/Titelseite;art692,2435009 Scientology – Zweifel an Verbotsplänen], article in [[Tagesspiegel]], 2007-12-8 {{Link language|de}}<!--German--></ref><ref>[https://www.welt.de/politik/article1439936/Innenminister_fordern_Verbot_von_Scientology.html Innenminister fordern Verbot von Scientology], article in [[Die Welt]], 2007-12-8 {{Link language|de}}<!--German--></ref> This view is echoed by the German intelligence agencies, who warn that a ban would be doomed to fail.<ref>{{cite web | title = Lack of Evidence: Agencies Warn Scientology Ban Doomed to Fail | url = http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,522348,00.html | work = | publisher = [[Der Spiegel]] | date = 2007-12-10 | accessdate = 2007-12-18 }}</ref>
===2008===
* Internet-based group [[Anonymous (group)|Anonymous]] launches [[Project Chanology]], a worldwide protest against the Church of Scientology, which drew about 7,000 people in more than 93 cities on February 10, 2008.<ref name="moncada"> {{cite news |author=Carlos Moncada |title=Organizers Tout Scientology Protest, Plan Another |url=http://suncoastpinellas.tbo.com/content/2008/feb/12/organizers-tout-scientology-protest-plan-another/ |work= |publisher=[[The Tampa Tribune|TBO.com]] |date=2008-02-12 |accessdate=2008-02-13 }} </ref>
* November: Germany drops its attempt to ban Scientology, after finding insufficient evidence of illegal or unconstitutional activity.<ref name=Drop>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2008/11/21/germany.html|title=Germany drops attempt to ban Scientology|date=November 21, 2008|publisher=|accessdate=March 1, 2015}}</ref> However, monitoring of Scientology's activities by the German intelligence services continues.<ref name=Drop />
===2009===
* Scientologists convicted of fraud in France on October 27, 2009.<ref name="francefraud"> {{cite news |author=Dorothee Moisan |title=Scientologists convicted of fraud in France |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iB4zZrgJt9_M4ltYiwOwQxcAnMmQ |work= |agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]] |date=2009-10-27 |accessdate=2009-10-28 }} </ref>

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} [[Image:Trialtrenches.jpg|thumb|Archaeological trial trenches]] '''Trial trenching''' is a rapid and inexpensive method of [[archaeological evaluation]] used to estimate the archaeological potential of a site.
Trenches are located at intervals across a site leaving the rest untouched. A mechanical excavator is used to dig down to archaeological features or natural geological deposits and any archaeology is recorded. No further excavation takes place at this stage. The results of the trial trenching are used to inform any future stage of work which may extend to full [[Excavation (archaeology)|excavation]] of the rest of the site if the evaluation reveals significant finds.
There is some argument over the [[sampling strategy]] to be employed in trial trenching, especially in evaluating sites that are intended for development. Issues such as the effectiveness of certain trench layouts or the percentage of the site to be dug (normally around 5% at present) are widely discussed. Whether an effective picture of past human activity on a site can be truly estimated through this methods is widely debated. Development can destroy buried archaeology forever and a reliable evaluation methodology is very important. Whilst it is difficult to quantify the number of [[Type I and type II errors|false negative]] results there have certainly been examples of evaluations suggesting a relatively limited amount of past activity which has had to be upwardly revised during the excavation.
In the UK the results of the trial trenching will be used to inform the decision on the need for any further archaeological work to be undertaken prior to development. This process is enshrined in [[PPG 16]] and [[English Heritage]]'s ''Management of Archaeological Projects'' colloquially known as [[MAP 2]].
==See also== *[[Archaeological field survey]] *[[Shovel test pit]] *[[Watching brief]] *[[Excavation (archaeology)|Excavation]]

{{Coord|10|48|18|N|106|39|40|E|type:airport|display=title}} The '''Vietnam People's Air Force Museum, Saigon''' or ''Bảo Tàng Phòng Không - Không Quân'' is located on ''Duong Thang Long'' (Thang Long Street) in the ''Phuong'' 4 District of [[Ho Chi Minh City]]. The museum is near to [[Tan Son Nhat International Airport]] and adjacent to the gate to [[Tan Son Nhut Air Base]].
The museum tells the history of the [[Vietnam People's Air Force]] (VPAF) in the [[Second Indochina War]] and the [[Cambodian-Vietnamese War]]. The museum comprises one main building with a small display of uniforms and flightsuits, aircraft weaponry and engines. Outside is a static park with aircraft of the VPAF and the [[Republic of Vietnam Air Force]].
The museum is open Tuesday-Thursday and weekends from 07:30 to 11:00 and 13:30 to 17:00. Admission is free.
==Aircraft on Display== Aircraft on outside display include:
*Bell [[UH-1 Iroquois]] H model *[[Cessna A-37 Dragonfly]] *[[Cessna U-17A]] *[[Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21]]MF *[[Mil Mi-8]] Hip *[[Mil Mi-24]] Hind A *[[Northrop F-5 Freedom Fighter]] <gallery> Image:MiG 21.jpg|MiG-21MF Image:Mi-24A.jpg|Mi-24A </gallery>
==See also== *[[Southeastern Armed Forces Museum Military Zone 7]] *[[War Remnants Museum]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Washington State Department of Archaeology & Historic Preservation |type = Department |logo_width = 180px |logo_caption = '''DAHP Logo'''
Motto: ''Protect the Past. Shape the Future'' |formed = 1967 |preceding1 = Washington State Office of Archaeology and Historic Preservation |jurisdiction = [[Washington (state)|Washington State Government]] |headquarters = [[Olympia, WA]] |employees = 18.3 FTE |chief1_name = Dr. Allyson Brooks |chief1_position = [[State Historic Preservation Officer|Director]] |chief2_name = Greg Griffith |chief2_position = [[State Historic Preservation Officer|Deputy Director]] |chief3_name = Dr. Rob Whitlam |chief3_position = State [[Archaeologist]] |chief4_name = Dr. Guy Tasa |chief4_position = State [[Biological anthropology|Physical Anthropologist]] |chief5_name = Michael Houser |chief5_position = State Architectural Historian |website = [http://dahp.wa.gov/ dahp.wa.gov] |seal=|budget=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} The '''Department of Archaeology and Historic Preservation''' (DAHP) is an independent government agency in [[Washington (state)|Washington state]] which serves several functions, including regulatory functions. The agency inventories and regulates [[archaeological sites]]; houses Washington's [[State Historic Preservation Officer]], State Archaeologist, State Architectural Historian and State Physical Anthropologist; maintains the Washington Heritage Register and [[Heritage Barn]] Register; provides expertise on environmental impacts to cultural resources; administers [[historic preservation]] grants for heritage barns and historic county courthouses; encourages historic preservation through local governments; provides technical assistance for historic rehabilitation and using historic preservation tax credits; and maintains extensive GIS databases to catalog the state's historic and prehistoric cultural resources. DAHP reviews an impressive number of projects. In Washington's 2008 fiscal year (July 1, 2007-June 30, 2008), DAHP reviewed 4,911 projects through the Section 106 process, 2,688 projects through the State SEPA process, and 1,336 reviews through the EO 0505 process."2008 Workload Trends" Government Management Accountability and Performance. Department of Archaeology and Historic Preservation. Olympia, WA. July 2008. ==History== Washington's State Historic Preservation Office was first created by Washington State Bill 363 in 1967. Within a year, the State Advisory Board convened for the first time, and it was staffed by the State Parks Department. Funding for the program was not secured until 1973, and coincided with the creation of the Washington Heritage Register. In 1975, the first Washington SHPO was appointed. The office bounced around for a time, cycling between independent agency and housed within another state agency. Most recently, DAHP became an independent agency after leaving the Washington State Department of Community, Trade and Economic Development (now the Washington State Department of Commerce, formerly the Department of Community Development and the Department of Trade and Economic Development) as the Office of Archaeology and Historic Preservation."Timeline" Michael Houser, Washington State Historic Preservation Office. http://www.dahp.wa.gov/pages/AboutUs/documents/WASTATESHPOTIMELINE_001.pdf DAHP was made into a state agency by the [[Washington State Legislature|Washington State HB 1706-2005]], and was codified into the Revised Code of Washington, 43.334.HB 1706-2005 http://apps.leg.wa.gov/documents/billdocs/2005-06/Pdf/Bills/House%20Bills/1706.pdfRCW 43.334 http://apps.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=43.334 ==Agency Functions== ===State Historic Preservation Officer=== DAHP houses Washington's State Historic Preservation Office (SHPO), a position created by the National Historic Preservation Act.National Historic Preservation Act, Section 101 http://www.achp.gov/docs/nhpa%202008-final.pdf The SHPO conducts reviews of the impacts to historic resources caused by construction funded by federal dollars under the authority of the National Historic Preservation Act, section 101.NHPA; Public Law 89-665; 16 U.S.C. 470 et seq.) Governor [[Christine Gregoire]]'s 2005 executive order, EO 05-05, further extended the Washington SHPO's authority to include the review of capital projects using state dollars.Executive Order 05-05 http://www.governor.wa.gov/execorders/eo_05-05.pdf Washington State designates DAHP as an agency with expertise in cultural resources under the State Environmental Protection Act (SEPA).WAC 197-11-920 http://apps.leg.wa.gov/wac/default.aspx?cite=197-11-920 The current Washington State Historic Preservation Officer is Dr. Allyson Brooks.DAHP Staff Directory http://www.dahp.wa.gov/pages/AboutUs/Staff.htm ===Governor's Advisory Board on Historic Preservation=== DAHP staffs the Governor's Advisory Board on Historic Preservation, which was established by RCW 27.34.250-330. The Board meets three or four times a year and reviews applications to the Washington Heritage Register and the National Register of Historic Places . It has nine members, including a representative of local or state heritage organizations, six members of the public who are interested and experienced in issues of preservation or archaeology, a representative from the Washington archaeological community, and a representative of the Native American community. Terms are four years. ===Archaeology Regulation=== Through Section 106 reviews (pursuant to the National Historic Preservation Act), and Washington's SEPA, DAHP reviews construction projects using federal or state monies for impacts to archaeological resources. Washington's archaeological resources are rich as [[History of Washington (state)#Prehistory|evidence of human activity stretches almost 13,000 years.]] Archaeology reviews are carried out by professional staff archaeologists. The current Washington State Archaeologist is Dr. Rob Whitlam. DAHP assigns site number ([[Smithsonian trinomial]]s) for archaeological sites, and maintains a database of over 18,000 archaeological sites in the state.Archaeology and DAHP http://www.dahp.wa.gov/pages/Archaeology/Survey.htm DAHP also regulates archaeological excavation in the state, and issues permits to applicants.RCW 27.53: Permit Regulation Authority http://apps.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=27.53.060 As archaeological records are confidential and exempt from public disclosure laws, DAHP also regulates research by archaeological consultants. To expand the ease and streamline construction planning, DAHP has created a pre-contact archaeological predictive model, which will give an overview of the likelihood of finding archaeological resources in any given area of the state. ===Built Environment=== The agency also features a robust [[built environment]] staff who review construction impacts to historic properties. This unit provides some technical assistance in historic preservation standards to local jurisdictions in addition to conducting reviews of historic resources. DAHP keeps track of Washington's properties on the National Register of Historic Places, as well as the Washington Heritage RegisterWashington Heritage Register http://www.dahp.wa.gov/pages/HistoricSites/documents/HistoricPlacesinWashingtonReport_006.pdf and the Heritage Barn Register. The current Washington State Architectural Historian is Michael Houser. ===Heritage Barns=== Substitute House bill 2115-2007SHB 2115 http://www.leg.wa.gov/pub/billinfo/2007-08/Pdf/Bills/House%20Passed%20Legislature/2115-S.PL.pdf established the Washington State Barn Preservation program, and charged DAHP with maintaining a Heritage Barn Register and administering grants programs for heritage barn owners. DAHP also staffs a Heritage Barn Preservation Advisory Board, which reviews applicants for heritage barn status. ===Human Remains=== DAHP was given statutory authority over all non-[[forensic science|forensic human remains]] found in the state by HB 2624-2008.HB 2624-2008 http://www.leg.wa.gov/pub/billinfo/2007-08/Pdf/Bills/House%20Bills/2624-S.pdf RCW 43.334.075 RCW 43.334.075 http://apps.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=43.334.075 requires that the State Physical Anthropologist hold a PhD in archaeology or anthropology or have an MD with experience in archaeology. DAHP gained jurisdiction starting in Washington State FY09 (July 1, 2008). The State Physical Anthropologist's primary responsibility is determining the origin and ethnicity of human remains, and repatriating these remains to the appropriate parties. The position was filled in August, 2008 by Dr. Guy Tasa. ==References== {{reflist}} {{Western U.S. historical societies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Washington State Department Of Archaeology And Historic Preservation}} [[Category:Washington (state) culture]] [[Category:Government of Washington (state)]] [[Category:Archaeological organisations]] [[Category:Historic preservation organizations in the United States]] [[Category:State agencies of Washington (state)|Archaeology and Historic Preservation]]
